title: How to Build a Lasting Community

rawLines.text: [Music]
we're going to kick off the afternoon
with Ted not lasso Ted not lasso is a
power user and self-described evangelist
of farcaster she's also the founder of
Club Ted which is an onchain membership
club experimenting at the frontier of
onchain communities and decentralized
social she recently organized far 2024
which was a multi-day summit to connect
and celebrate the forecaster Community
previously she led Biz Ops and strategy
at Goldfinch which is which was one of
the first real world asset protocols and
is also in our portfolio she helped
scale it from seed to series a and to
100 million plus in AUM so let's welcome
Ted I'm here today to talk about how to
build a sustainable community community
is a buzzword I think everybody knows
that you might be looking and you're
like okay this morning learned about how
to build an audience how to Market how
to connect with your users and I think
Community is inherently a part of that
but just as a audience is different than
a community a community is also
different than a network and so
hopefully I can demonstrate and outline
the differences today and convince you
the importance of really focusing and
honing in on how to build your own
Community I as car mentioned am a early
power user of farcast asor turned
evangelist turned Community Builder so I
think I'm the perfect example of what
happens when a Founder focuses on
community-led growth and really allows
the users of their protocol or their
product to feel a sense of ownership and
be able to um leverage that ownership to
create kind of my own Vision my own
reality my own platform as well a little
bit of background is before I worked in
crypto and before I moved full-time into
crypto I actually helped build kind of
like 0er to1 new products features
campaigns etc for Brands celebrities
startups and family offices and
something that's consistent across all
of these is that they all focused at
their stage on community-led growth so
Brands pretty self kind of
self-explanatory Gucci huge huge brand
they focus on House of Gucci all for
their celebrities they focus on
community and user generated content
they focus on different activations
that's straightforward celebrities also
straightforward worked with Miley and
Madonna and fandom for them is is
everything right so like how are these
celebrities connecting with their fans
how are they making sure that their fans
feel part of a community I think Taylor
Swift is like the best example of this I
know it's a silly to uh reference Taylor
Swift but uh everything from like the
little bracelets all of the friendship
bracelets that she makes at her concerts
to the Easter eggs that she leaves in
albums like all of that is part of
building community and then startups as
well especially Marketplace startups so
like how do you allow all kind of facets
of the marketplace to feel connected it
allows you to have some stickiness and
then does anyone know what this it's
small but does anyone know what this
place is it is the Sun Valley Conference
so where all of the billionaires family
offices Etc go and so you might think oh
family offices they don't really need
Community they're operating in their own
world at the end of the day they too are
looking for community and so take a step
back I would say what what is community
um I think a lot of people have
different definitions of it and my
definition would be like what are the
interactions the relationships and the
value that's derived between members of
the community so a really easy analogy
would be um you live in an apartment
complex and you know you could go in and
out and not talk to anybody so even
though you're in the same vicinity
you're in the same network you're not
necessarily part of a community whereas
if you kind of like move down the street
and all of a sudden interacting with
everybody you're talking there's value
being exchanged that to me is a
community this is my background working
with kind of like all these web two
players in the space and so I got really
excited when we think about web 3 and
using tokens to continue to grow
Community Chris Dixon said tokens line
Network participants to work together
toward a common goal so the growth of
the network and the appreciation of
token this was really exciting because
you could potentially turn Community
into a core part of these businesses
because it so intrinsically allows you
to line incentives for Collective growth
so tokens we thought could solve this
what I think many people in crypto have
learned is that how we thought it would
work in theory is not how it works in
practice and so what we've seen is that
all of a sudden if you use a token to
hopefully let's say like address the
cold start problem so oh you're using a
token in order to like bootstrap your
community what you may end up with is
what it says in this tweet is that
you're left with empty discords or
discords just asking one token one
airdrop and so I'd almost say look take
a step back Back to Basics is give users
ownership and they will help you build
something important and I think crypto
is so ingrained into thinking about
ownership in terms of a token and
meanwhile there's many many meaningful
ways to give users a sense of ownership
before you introduce a token and that's
what I think we should all focus on
today and what I will focus on also
because uh that's my experience how many
of you Founders are technical by raise
of hands okay good how many of you have
ever worked in like a formal marketing
or Community role
before okay very few um so I think one
thing that's scary about The Word
Community is that a community inherently
is like more operationally heavy than
and product L growth right so you have
to be in the weeds you have to be
talking to users you have to be doing
all of this what I would argue is that
you can actually build community by
Building Product and that at an early
stage company product Le growth and
Community Le growth can actually be hand
inand and they work really closely
together because a lot of the stuff that
you're trying to figure out on the
product side can actually be outsourced
or leveraged by the community so first
of that is build with your users not for
them so I'll run through kind of like
four key principles this being the first
Dan who is the founder co-founder of
forecaster I've learned a ton from him
he included this in his CSX presentation
from LA and basically it's the idea of
dog fooding I'm sure this isn't new to
you guys but it's be your own first user
why this is important on the product
side you already know but why this is
important on the community side is that
it allows you to empathize and be
authentic to your kind of like first
core group of users so that means you
have the firsthand experience of user
pain points you understand like why
somebody might love your your product
you understand who might be the user of
the product too so you can start small
and make sure that you're focusing on
like a really small Core group of people
and then you can understand okay where
where might I find these people too and
that I think is the most important
question is okay once I understand all
these pain points once I'm using this
product every day once I'm understanding
like where do they where do they GA like
you ask where do they gather and that's
where you should go to start building
your community so I know you heard from
ish this morning about like where are
you building your social presence in
theory it would be great if you build
your social Presence at the same place
that you're building your community as
well also this isn't necessarily new so
this is uh you guys are familiar with
the uh Homebrew Computer Club is this
ringing a bell yeah W and Steve ended up
tinkering building their own computers
figuring it all out and then they would
go exactly to where their future users
would go which is Homebrew Computer Club
they would go they would bring their
product they would get feed back they
would meet other people there and I
think that is is really important cuz
they're users of their own product and
they're part of the community without
inherently being like oh we're going to
go build a community right and so this
is like an example of if you're building
with your users and not for them you're
ultimately just doing product and
community at the same time so it's not
necessarily an outsourced function that
you need to be thinking about you're in
the weeds you're you're doing everything
that you need to be doing the second
principle here is Foster authentic
connections I think authenticity is King
I don't think that's relatively new to
anybody and I think what this means in
terms of building Community as an early
stage founder is providing like high
touch personalized experiences for early
users and and a lot of times this means
like do things that don't scale so this
famous Paul Graham quote the hardest
thing for all of you is probably like
going out and finding users and so again
going back to kind of like build with
your community not for them if you if
you're dog fooding the product you know
who where you can go find those like
initial 20 25 to 50 early early users
power users could be and then kind of
doing things that don't scale providing
High touch engagement is kind of like
here's this is actually again from Dan
go out and onboard them personally make
time to to hold hands with them and say
okay here's the product what's your
feedback how are you doing this and a
lot of people might be like oh this is
this is what I'm just doing this like
get feedback but it's really about
building a genuine relationship like a
lot of work that goes into what you're
what the what the product should be
doing like the community does a lot of
that work right so like you're sitting
there you're Gathering all this feedback
and then you can iterate and share it
with them and so then they're they're
feeling bought in by doing this like
onetoone Personal Touch and this doesn't
mean like sending out a mass email or
kind of like oh like having somebody
else on your team do it it's like
personal onetoone Outreach what that
looked like for me as I led up to Faron
was going and spending time with a lot
of the farcaster community and this
isn't a lot different ways so I think
something else that I love that aot Gil
says in kind of like the high growth
handbook is to run many small
experiments because the goal is to find
scalable repeatable me methods to in his
case acquire customers in my case it was
to build community and so do a lot of
things um kind of is the advice that
would give so the first is like okay we
this crazy story on the kind of right
here is that for a bunch of people I was
like okay I want to walk a marathon in
LA from Dodger Stadium all the way to
Venice Beach who wants to do it with me
like crazy idea was like nobody would
want to do this also definitely not
scalable and like in this photo there's
like 12 people who are like yes I'm
totally down all internet strangers all
only knew each other through
farcaster all decided to like okay let's
do this let's walk a marathon and it
ended up becoming a almost like the full
foraster community was bought into it so
the people who are walking it all
strangers now all friends like two of my
best friends are from that and then
beyond that we basically captured the
entire like mile by mile and shared it
on the platform so that people felt
bought in along the way as well and so
that was just like a really fun moment
where you're like oh this is like a
silly small experiment what worked what
clicked here um and so just like go out
and be with the community it's also been
like small dinners um you can see here I
had a bunch of read write own books and
was like Hey does anyone in the
community want them um I'll send them to
you personally and so that's another
thing is all of a sudden I just wrote a
nice handwritten note I think I sent out
like 40 books I actually ended up having
to buy them in order to uh make sure
that everyone got one um I offered poker
we did live streams we just did a ton of
different experiments to be like okay
how can users contribute to each other
so learning like oh I'm I'm listening to
them and creating an interactive space
for them to engage with each other and
so it's a lot easier for me to
understand okay like what value do I add
as a community member what value are
they adding adding to each other and
like what does a sense of ownership
actually mean for this community so from
there like once a you've dog you kind of
have used your own product gone to where
they are and then engaged directly with
them to build authentic relationships
the next step is to create like genuine
Collective ownership again give users
ownership and they will help you build
something important there's lots of ways
you can go about this I'll show two um
one of them is the concept of like
psychological ownership right and so I
think Dan a forecaster does a really
phenomenal job with this and that like
every 2 weeks or every month he'll ask
if you were like benevolent dictator of
warcast what would you do differently
what would you have us focus on what
features would you add and so this is a
way of kind of like allowing users to
have a say or influence in the in the
direction of the product I think this is
really powerful because a you're getting
kind of like direct feedback no one's
going to BS that right like if they
don't care then they won't comment
otherwise people who care will comment
so get to collect that data then you can
iterate or you can build out some of
those features and then you can launch
and like close the loop back so a it's
like a really great product feedback
loop but B they all feel a sense of
ownership because they're like oh wow
like he listened to me and like oh I
have a good idea for the product and oh
they implemented it like I I am have
skin in the game now I want to keep
participating um fun story about me is
that actually I was I reported all of
the bugs I was like screenshots and the
the bug screenshot send the bug this is
when there was like only 200 users on
the platform so there was like I was
like oh who liked my post and like every
time it was just Dan and once they
decided to get into the App Store and
get out of like flight test my he like
used my profile in the App Store kind of
like little Carousel wheel and I can't
tell you like how special that made me
feel I was like wow I I can't believe he
like noticed that I send all these bugs
he said thank you for doing the bug
reports and for me that kind of turned
me into the evangelist because I was
like oh they care about the community
and it's not just like entirely self-
serving like they they care kind of we
did the same or I did the same thing
with farcon saying okay as soon as we
announced and we started getting
applications we were like who wants to
be involved how do you want to be
involved just comment and reply here
again I would say like this isn't
scalable because for both Dan and for
farcon like you get hundreds of
responses and so you can't keep doing
that over and over and over again but it
is one of the things where it's like if
you ask for feedback you're engaging
with your users again this is this is
good for the product it's also building
community at the same time so hopefully
like I I think one thing we'll say over
and over and over again is what is good
for the product is also good for the
community and so I don't want Community
to be this like big scary like woo woo
thing it's like oh no no if you're doing
what is good for the product and product
development you should also kind of like
this isn't inherently part of it as well
so one other thing is again I think I
mentioned earlier if you are leaning
into Community another way to make
people feel like a collective sense of
ownership is to highlight or create
opportunities for them to fully
contribute so for farcon I guess the
best way to say it is like obviously
there's so many aspects of running an
event there's like applications
ticketing uh onboarding the programming
itself um kind of like what activities
there are going to be uh social Etc
marketing
and what we tried to do was like fully
Outsource it to the community and so
every single stakeholder who was
providing some sort of service or
helping with the programming felt
completely bought in and so they also
wanted to make it the best event ever
because they had some sort of
responsibility also the way that I
thought about it was like we're hosting
an event of 500 of very onchain people
who could Pro probably provide each of
these Founders who kind of helped
participate whether it was form hypers
sub um um there's ice breaker there's
events XYZ there's friends there's
bracket so you can see all of these it's
like okay you're going to get kind of
like really high fidelity high quality
feedback from all 500 of these users if
you kind of like help and participate
and become part of the fabric of farcon
as well and so thinking about he how can
I provide value to them allows them to
enter in and then feels like okay again
I have skin in the game I want to be
have like a meaningful contribution
again builds community so that is one
and then the last principle I would
include here is scaling through
community-led experiences how many of
you guys use
notion a lot I don't know if how many of
you are actually familiar with like the
lore of notion but they Jason I think
his name is Jason Lem he was actually
kind of the same exact story of me power
user of notion created all these
templates decided he wanted to include
them in his newsletter all of a sudden
someone from notion realized he was
doing this and was like oh my gosh do
you just want to join the team and be
like head of our community or head of
growth and what he was really focused on
was kind of like this template Gallery
because that's how he started to gain
traction and so in terms of like create
community-led experiences this can be as
simple as user generated content like
not everyone here can be like Oh I'm
going to host like a 5day 500 person
Summit and like drop everything else
that I'm doing in order to bring the
community together so there's kind of
like easier more remote and more
scalable ways and number one is user
generated content so here's their
template Gallery I think they did the
template Gallery they also did kind of
an ambassador program so they went and
identified let's say community of
Angeles like Jason or others kind of all
across the world and said okay how can
we help you what do you need um how can
we help you kind of like basically reach
your audience or increase the audience
what this looks like for forecast
is on the product side this is where I
think product and Community Le growth go
hand inand on the product side in
warcast they launched an explore page
which is ultimately like an App Store so
here's all of what kind of like
developer tools developer apps that
people have made directly within the
warcast app and developers were so
excited they were like this is
incredible how do we keep iterating on
this they felt like okay we're getting
distribution we're getting to see kind
of like more users are using our apps
but they couldn't be happier on the
community side kind of as we decided to
lean into developers it also meant like
hosting forecaster developer day and
bringing everyone together to continue
to get kind of like straight feedback
with the developers and the core meracle
team also on the community side is okay
we have these apps in the store um or in
in the Explorer page how do we actually
get users to use them and so I launched
this thing called forecaster Fridays
where the first Friday of every month
you just do a casual Meetup in your city
with other forecasters and we encourage
everyone to use some of the apps that
are included in the explore page as well
so not only are you bringing developers
together on the community side which is
informing the product you're also
bringing users together which then
inform kind of like all of the the
developer applications and then also
kind of the core team as well I would
say like this is where the feedback loop
gets really helpful is again like once
you I think at any early stage product
lead growth and Community lead growth
they are two different things but they
should be working hand inand or in
parallel moving from these four key
principles into some more concrete
tactics build with your users not for
them so I would say a use your product
every single day um be your own first
user be able to focus on user needs so
that you can lead with empathy and
authenticity so when I worked at
Goldfinch for instance we were focusing
on kind of like investors right and I
wasn't the type of person to be
investing every day that's just not me
so what is something else that I was I
was doing I was finding a friend who
could be that who was that type of
person who did want to invest who knew
the private credit or the traditional
Finance space and I basically checked in
with them kind of like at least weekly
to be like oh do you want to walk
through this with me again what are some
pain points you have and tried to be as
okay if I'm not using it every day or I
I would use it and then i' go to them
and be like oh this was weird what do
you think about this so if you aren't
using it every day I would just
encourage you to find a proxy to to use
it every day but you should be using it
every day again to identify a small
group of Target users and go where they
already are so in much the same way that
is said okay like focus on one platform
because that's easy I think there's so
many platforms out there there's Discord
there's Twitter there's telegram there's
kind of like infinite options available
obviously there's worldcast or
forecaster um I'm biased in where I
prefer to spend my time but for
everybody else just go where your users
already are like you don't want to have
to ask somebody to download an a whole
new app and like Port them over just to
use your product unless and they they
probably won't do that unless your
product is solving like a dying need for
them that's number two and then three
ask for feedback constantly and then
iterate quickly and then ask for
feedback again and so I think as
Founders everybody trusts their own
intuition right like you probably know
what the product needs you know what
your priorities are but just because you
already have those answers internally
doesn't mean that you shouldn't be
continuously asking for feedback um it's
your job as a to be able to like look at
a whole list of comments and be like
okay this is high priority this is not
high priority or like understand the
second or third order effects of what
some of the feedback May entail but you
should constantly be asking for feedback
I think that there's a report that just
came out that said that the founder of
pump. fund ended up dming like 500 or
5,000 people before it started getting
traction like literally went and was
like hey are you using my product why
aren't you using my product what's wrong
with it and that's kind of like do
things that don't scale like go out and
and be continuously asking for feedback
and also just like develop thick skin
too because some of the feedback like
you might not want to hear uh and it's
good to get that um because the worst
thing that can happen is you do a huge
product launch and then you end up
delivering a product that a ton of
people don't really love or don't want
and then you you wish that you had asked
kind of for smaller bites of feedback
along the way number two some tactical
ideas for foster authentic connection so
first one I've mentioned multiple times
like start with high touch send personal
DMS and replies if you guys are building
a social presence and you're
uncomfortable building a personal brand
and like putting a bunch of stuff out
there the best way that you can approach
building a social presence and building
Community is by actually acting as like
customer support for people who have
questions about your product so that's
part of your job as a Founder is to kind
of like service all of your users and to
provide them support and so if you think
about it and you're like oh somebody
kind of mentioned this topic or somebody
mentioned our company like you should be
responding to that as the founder again
I think Jason Leven says it's a product
hunt he's like I send personal DMS all
the time if I'm sending it from the
brand account I even say like hi it's
Jason like I would love to talk to you
about this and so again like anything
you can do to provide personal Outreach
is so so valuable two Embrace building
in public and share the behind the
scenes so this is the part that I think
any body who's ambition or driven
doesn't necessarily like to do you want
to share all of your wins um I think
it's really helpful to share any part of
the as of kind of like of the journey so
it builds trust it makes kind of like
it's very transparent it builds
authenticity as well so what this looks
like I think for farcon there was a time
I was like working full-time job trying
to host this event and I fell super
behind on kind of replying to DMS and uh
people were upset and I just had to
straight up come out and be like hey
guys I'm really sorry I'm super behind
on getting back to everyone I promise
I'll take the time over the weekend to
do it here's a little bit more
visibility into what next steps are we
haven't figured out the answer but kind
of here's where our focus is right now
and after that kind of all of the anger
or tension or just like frustration from
users dissipated because I gave them a
look into okay here's what's going on
behind the scenes and I always feel like
it's better to be proactive especially
early and when there isn't a major
crisis than to just like sit back and
and wait and then three create space for
casual interactions so um a good example
of this is informal amas I was hosting
like online poker games you could host
like a casual live stream or a Twitter
space what I also like to call is is
office hours just create a space for
users to interact with each other so
obviously it's different if you're
building a social platform where kind of
like the product inherently is social
but even if you're building an
infrastructure platform uh kind of like
dii anything like that just creating a
space where your power users can come
and interact with you live is highly
valuable and get somebody on your team
if like if you're not feeling
particularly extroverted get someone on
your team to kind of just like encourage
and and welcome people and bring kind of
like positive energy because it could be
that the first time you host it only one
person decides to talk but there will be
other people listening in and that's
still a win and then the second time you
host it kind of maybe three people will
decide to talk and then the four or
third or fourth time more and more
people will get involved especially if
you create a like positive interaction
where they're like oh I did learn from
that or oh I met somebody who is worth
connecting with and I want to connect
with them again create genuine
Collective ownership so some tactics is
to create clear paths for users to shape
the Network's future this is very
obvious if you think about kind of some
of the questions or polls is like hey
what would you do if you were kind of
benevolent dictator forecaster or oh hey
what do you guys want to see um on the
farcon side we basically pulled and said
what types of activities would you guys
want to have at a 5-day conference and
it came down to Art music pickle ball
and uh hackathon uh closing ceremony so
just constantly think okay when you're
let's say releasing a new product or
thinking about different things what are
ways in which your power users can
contribute it could be content it could
be code it could be uh support um so
kind of like on that line it's like
create spaces for users to help solve
each other's problems so again probably
one of the high
operational effort things that you will
do is provide personalized customer
support which a is great because you're
getting product feedback but B is
definitely taxing and may not be kind of
like your favorite way to spend your
time if you build a community and allow
them to have like open Q&A whether
you're using a forum whether you're
using Twitter spaces whether you're
seeing other people do this this is kind
of like where you end up getting to open
up your bandwidth and then you can focus
on higher leverage things but make sure
that there's somehow like users can be
answering each other's questions and
then I think really importantly is build
a system for recognizing the community's
contributions so again the same way that
I was featured in the little app store
preview or we used a lot of the farters
artists artwork in farcon you need to be
recognizing when your community does
something it can be something so small
and even like a retweet or a reply
anything like that goes a very long way
especially today where I think you can
be so focused on your product and forget
that oh there are people who are super
passionate and excited about what you're
building and by engaging with them and
recognizing that they then feel a sense
of ownership and want to continue being
part of the community and then last
scale through Community Le experiences
is establish a culture and identity for
early users someone once's told me that
the best thing product that forecaster
has made is actually a strong cultural
identity and that everyone is kind of a
techno Optimist collaborative um kind of
like high integrity wants to help each
other that actually is what has
attracted and retained most of the users
more so than the product itself and so
by creating this like strong culture and
identity and I think this kind of lends
itself really nicely to what ish
discussed this morning you actually then
can allow people to build community
because it's kind of almost like
religion in a way it's like oh you and I
are similar let's go find other similar
people and bring them into the fold as
well something else identify any
emerging evangelists and engage them
directly so this is key um as you start
to recruit those like first 25 to 50
users it'll become pretty apparent like
who is High Fidelity and highly engaged
and make sure you continue engaging them
because that person can then go out and
recruit let's say like 5 to 10 more
users if they love the experience you're
going to share it and I think we unell
that a lot in crypto we think oh okay if
if they build it they will come they
likely won't you need to have like let's
say five evangelists to go out and
convince others to come into the fold as
well and then I think three is in order
to scale some of the community you need
to create consistent rituals um so what
this looks like is for foraster they do
something called like forecaster Friday
it's kind of like a thing is like oh if
we're going to launch a new feature
we're going to do it on Friday I think
that's against most conventional wisdom
is like don't launch something on Friday
because you'll be busy all weekend but
it's become this fun thing where all of
the users now are like oh is there like
a forecaster Friday is there going to be
a feature and then we played off of
thought into making forecaster Friday
actually like an in-person Community
experience as well so some of these
